The issue of limiting presidential powers was postponed until after the elections as part of the new constitution drafting process.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12589425 |title=BBC News - Egypt's army passes draft constitutional amendments |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2011-02-26 |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>
The issue of limiting presidential powers was postponed until after the elections as part of the new constitution drafting process.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12589425 |title=BBC News - Egypt's army passes draft constitutional amendments |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2011-02-26 |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>
â
If the referendum results in a "no" vote, the current constitution will be scrapped and a new one will be drawn up before elections, likely extending the planned transition period, with elections delayed to 2012.<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12763313</ref>
+
If the referendum results in a "no" vote, the current constitution will be scrapped and a new one will be drawn up before elections, likely extending the planned transition period, with elections delayed to 2012.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12763313 |title=BBC News - Q&A: Egypt's constitutional referendum |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2011-02-11 |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>
== The old articles from constitution ==
== The old articles from constitution ==
Line 108: Line 108:
}}
}}
â
A strong opposition coalition (including presidential candidates [[Amr Moussa]] and [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], the [[New Wafd Party]], the [[Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution]], the [[National Progressive Unionist Party]], the [[el-Ghad Party]] and the [[Egyptian Arab Socialist Party]]) criticized the amendments as not enough are that the new constitution needs to be written now to regulate the process and the requirements for the members of the Parliament. They also criticized that the president's power were not limited with the proposed changes; the opposition coalition also criticized that early elections would benefit the NDP and the Muslim Brotherhood (see below).<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12763313</ref>
+
A strong opposition coalition (including presidential candidates [[Amr Moussa]] and [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], the [[New Wafd Party]], the [[Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution]], the [[National Progressive Unionist Party]], the [[el-Ghad Party]] and the [[Egyptian Arab Socialist Party]]) criticized the amendments as not enough are that the new constitution needs to be written now to regulate the process and the requirements for the members of the Parliament. They also criticized that the president's power were not limited with the proposed changes; the opposition coalition also criticized that early elections would benefit the NDP and the Muslim Brotherhood (see below).<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
===The Yes Camp ===
===The Yes Camp ===
â
The [[Muslim Brotherhood]] and the [[Salafi]] movement (including famous Salafi preachers {{link-interwiki|en=Mohammed Hassan|lang=ar|lang_title=ÙØ­ÙØ¯ Ø­Ø³Ø§Ù}} and {{link-interwiki|en=Mohammed Abdel Maksoud|lang=ar|lang_title=ÙØ­ÙØ¯ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§ÙÙÙØµÙØ¯}}<ref>http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/362640</ref>), among other Islamist groups in Egypt, think that the amendments are suitable for the time being and that the situation in Egypt is not perfect to write a new constitution right away. They have used fear tactics saying that '''Article 2''' of the Constitution of Egypt (which states ''Islam is the Religion of the State. Arabic is its official language, and the principal source of legislation is Islamic Jurisprudence ([[Sharia]])''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.egypt.gov.eg/english/laws/constitution/chp_one/part_one.aspx |title=EgyptÃ¢â¬â¢s Government Services Portal - Egypt Constitution - Chapter one: The State |publisher=Egypt.gov.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>) will removed or changed if they did not vote Yes<ref>http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/362640</ref> even though ''constitutional amendment committee'' said that Article II will not be touched<ref>http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/324621</ref>. Sheikh [[Yusuf al-Qaradawi]] advised the Egyptians on the 18 of March to vote Yes on constitutional referendum.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=422881&version=1&template_id=36&parent_id=16 |title=Gulf Times â Qatarâs top-selling English daily newspaper - Qatar |publisher=Gulf-times.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref> The [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] also have asked their base to vote Yes<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/1/64/7971/Egypt/Politics-/Egyptian-Islamists,-along-with-NDP,-campaign-hard-.aspx |title=Egyptian Islamists, along with NDP, campaign hard for a "Yes" vote on Constitutional amendments - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>.
+
The [[Muslim Brotherhood]] and the [[Salafi]] movement (including famous Salafi preachers {{link-interwiki|en=Mohammed Hassan|lang=ar|lang_title=ÙØ­ÙØ¯ Ø­Ø³Ø§Ù}} and {{link-interwiki|en=Mohammed Abdel Maksoud|lang=ar|lang_title=ÙØ­ÙØ¯ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§ÙÙÙØµÙØ¯}}<ref name="Religious propaganda, vote-buying flourish in Egypt ahead of vote">{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/362640 |title=Religious propaganda, vote-buying flourish in Egypt ahead of vote | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>), among other Islamist groups in Egypt, think that the amendments are suitable for the time being and that the situation in Egypt is not perfect to write a new constitution right away. They have used fear tactics saying that '''Article 2''' of the Constitution of Egypt (which states ''Islam is the Religion of the State. Arabic is its official language, and the principal source of legislation is Islamic Jurisprudence ([[Sharia]])''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.egypt.gov.eg/english/laws/constitution/chp_one/part_one.aspx |title=EgyptÃ¢â¬â¢s Government Services Portal - Egypt Constitution - Chapter one: The State |publisher=Egypt.gov.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>) will removed or changed if they did not vote Yes<ref name="eligious propaganda, vote-buying flourish in Egypt ahead of vote"/> even though ''constitutional amendment committee'' said that Article II will not be touched<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/324621 |title=Constitutional amendment committee: Article II will not be touched | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=2011-02-20 |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>. Sheikh [[Yusuf al-Qaradawi]] advised the Egyptians on the 18 of March to vote Yes on constitutional referendum.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=422881&version=1&template_id=36&parent_id=16 |title=Gulf Times â Qatarâs top-selling English daily newspaper - Qatar |publisher=Gulf-times.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref> The [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] also have asked their base to vote Yes<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/1/64/7971/Egypt/Politics-/Egyptian-Islamists,-along-with-NDP,-campaign-hard-.aspx |title=Egyptian Islamists, along with NDP, campaign hard for a "Yes" vote on Constitutional amendments - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>.
â
The Muslim Brotherhood and the NDP are also perceived to be in favour of a "yes" vote because early elections would benefit them the most, as they have already got a good organization established, while smaller and newly-founded parties would have little time to prepare for elections in the planned schedule.<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12763313</ref>
+
The Muslim Brotherhood and the NDP are also perceived to be in favour of a "yes" vote because early elections would benefit them the most, as they have already got a good organization established, while smaller and newly-founded parties would have little time to prepare for elections in the planned schedule.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
